channel.title: Bloomberg Politics

item.title: Trump to Appeal Tariffs Ruling While Weighing Other Ways to Implement Levies
item.description: President Donald Trump’s appetite for new tariffs remains undeterred, even after a court hit his signature duties with their most devastating blow yet.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Jennifer A Dlouhy

item.title: What’s Next for Trump’s Trade War After Court Blocks Tariffs
item.description: The US Court of International Trade has blocked the vast majority of President Donald Trump’s tariffs, dealing a blow to a key pillar of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Josh Wingrove, Shawn Donnan, Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump holds a poster detailing the reciprocal tariffs during an announcement in the White House Rose Garden in Washington, DC, on April 2, 2025. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Harvard Reprieve From Foreign Student Ban Extended by Judge
item.description: Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on the school enrolling international students.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: Harvard University students walk through Harvard Square in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on May 29. Photographer: Mel Musto/Bloomberg

item.title: Starmer Takes on Farage, Reeves Takes on Pensions: Ailbhe Rea
item.description: We crossed a Rubicon today, in more ways than one. Keir Starmer said for the first time that British politics is now a straight fight between his Labour and Nigel Farage’s Reform, while Rachel Reeves has confirmed she will force large pension funds to back British assets if they do not do so voluntarily.
item.dc:creator: Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, left, and Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, during a business reception on the sidelines of the UK-EU summit, at Downing Street in London, UK, on Monday, May 19, 2025. Prime Minister Keir Starmer heralded a deal to strengthen post-Brexit relations with the European Union after opposition politicians criticized a late climbdown by UK negotiators over fishing rights. Photographer: Tolga Akmen/EPA

item.title: US May Take Trump Tariff Case to Supreme Court on Friday
item.description: The Trump administration said it would ask the US Supreme Court to intervene as soon as Friday if a federal appeals court doesn’t immediately put on hold a decision finding that most of the president’s tariffs are illegal.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Jan. 10, 2025. Supreme Court justices signaled they are likely to uphold a law that would ban the popular social media platform TikTok in the US if it isn’t sold by its Chinese parent company by Jan. 19.

item.title: Russia Accuses Serbia of Backstabbing With Arms Sales to Ukraine
item.description: Russia accused Serbia of selling weaponry to Ukraine through third countries, potentially straining a relationship with a traditional ally that relies on Moscow for its energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier loads ammunition into an M2 Browning machine gun during a handover of mobile anti-aircraft pick-up trucks by Herocar, as part of the Guardians of the Sky project, at Gostomel airfield, outside Kyiv, Ukraine, on Saturday, April 1, 2023. The International Monetary Fund’s board signed off on a $15.6 billion aid package for Ukraine, the final approval for the institution’s first-ever loan to a nation at war. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel’s Katz: New Settlements Aim to Halt Palestine State
item.description: Israel will build 22 new settlements in the West Bank including some along its eastern border with Jordan, a development the nation’s defense minister said would “strengthen its grip on the territory” and “prevent the establishment of a Palestinian state.”
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: A Palestinian laborer works at a construction site in the Israeli settlement of Maale Adumim, in the West Bank in February 2024.

item.title: Spain Blackout Blame Game Heats Up as Iberdrola Points to Grid
item.description: Spain’s grid operator and the country’s largest utility took to public finger-wagging over their roles during the country’s biggest-ever blackout.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: An unlit residential street with no street lighting during power outage in Molins de Rei, Spain, Spain, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Spain and Portugal lost power shortly after 12:30 p.m. local time in a massive blackout that idled public transport, airports and phone services, bringing the daily activities of millions to a halt.

item.title: Musk’s No. 2 Also Departing DOGE as Officials Hit Time Limit
item.description: Steve Davis, who served as Elon Musk’s de facto second-in-command at the Department of Government Efficiency, is following the billionaire adviser out of President Donald Trump’s signature cost-cutting effort, a person familiar with the move said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk and Steve Davis in 2018.

item.title: Trump Sees Iran Deal That Allows US to Destroy Nuclear Sites
item.description: US President Donald Trump said he envisions a nuclear deal with Iran that would allow the destruction of “whatever we want” in the country including labs, a version of an inspections regime that is likely to be rejected by Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Jonathan Tirone

media:content.media:description: The reactor building at the Bushehr nuclear power plant in Bushehr, Iran, in a handout image supplied by the Iran International Photo Agency.

item.title: Harvard President Embraces Foreign Students at Commencement
item.description: Harvard University President Alan Garber played up the school’s international reach at its commencement ceremony as the institution battles the Trump administration over its right to enroll foreign students.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Alan Garber Photographer: Craig F. Walker/Boston Globe/Getty Images

item.title: Spain’s Iberdrola, Endesa Aim to Extend Nuclear Plant Lifespan
item.description: Spain’s three largest utilities are working on a proposal to extend the lifespan of the country’s biggest nuclear power plant, whose reactors are slated to be shut down in 2027 and 2028.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: The Nuclear Power Plant of Almaraz in Caceres.

item.title: IMF Approves $500 Million Ukraine Payment as Peace Talks Stall
item.description: The International Monetary Fund reached a deal with Ukraine to disburse the next portion of a $15.5 billion loan package for the war-battered nation.
item.dc:creator: Volodymyr Verbianyi

media:content.media:description: Rescuers outside a house destroyed by a Russian attack in Markhalivka village, Ukraine, on May 25.

item.title: Ishiba Calls Trump to Talk Tariffs, Touts Deeper Understanding
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba initiated a phone call with US President Donald Trump to discuss tariffs, and said the two deepened their understanding.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Shigeru Ishiba and Donald Trump. Photographer: Kyodo News/Kyodo News Stills

item.title: Nvidia Faces Bipartisan Concern on China Research Facility Plans
item.description: Republican Senator Jim Banks and Democrat Elizabeth Warren are demanding answers from Nvidia Corp. CEO Jensen Huang on his firm’s reported plans to open a research facility in Shanghai, saying the decision “raises significant national security and economic security concerns.”
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Jensen Huang

item.title: Reform’s Farage Sets Out Trump-Style Bid to Make UK a Crypto Hub
item.description: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage will attempt to woo younger British voters by announcing a Donald Trump-style foray into cryptocurrency policy at an Bitcoin conference in Las Vegas late on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Nigel Farage on May 27.

item.title: Trump Advisers Downplay Ruling Blocking Tariffs, Cite Other Options
item.description: Senior White House officials on Thursday downplayed the implications of a court ruling that blocked a swath of President Donald Trump’s tariff measures, and expressed confidence about an appeal.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: A train enters the United States over a rail bridge on the US-Mexico border in Laredo, Texas, US, on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2025. President Donald Trump said he would likely impose tariffs on automobile, semiconductor and pharmaceutical imports of around 25%, a move that would dramatically widen the president’s trade war.

item.title: Trump Takes Aim at Chinese Students and Tech, Threatening to Upset Truce With Xi
item.description: Just weeks after US President Donald Trump declared a “total reset” with China following a trade truce in Geneva, tensions are rising again between the world’s biggest economies.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: The Harry Elkins Widener Memorial Library at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, on May 27. Photographer: Sophie Park/Bloomberg

item.title: Texas Follows Florida in Republican Push to Remake US Colleges
item.description: Texas Republicans are tightening their grip on the state’s sprawling university systems amid a nationwide drive by conservatives to remake higher education.
item.dc:creator: Joe Lovinger

media:content.media:description: Texas A&M campus in College Station, Texas, in 2023.

item.title: South Africa to Probe Delays in Prosecuting Apartheid Crimes
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa established a commission of inquiry to determine whether attempts were made to prevent the investigation and prosecution of apartheid-era crimes.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa

item.title: Taiwan Says US Trade-Deal Push Continues Despite Court Ruling
item.description: Taiwan is continuing its efforts to secure a trade deal with the US, a top official said, even after a court blocked many of the tariffs that President Donald Trump has threatened to impose on other countries.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Miaojung Lin, Yvonne Man

media:content.media:description: The Port of Keelung in Keelung, Taiwan.

item.title: Starmer Acknowledges Farage’s Reform UK Is Main Labour Rival
item.description: Keir Starmer said Britain’s main opposition Conservative Party is in decline and that the choice for voters is now between his governing Labour Party and the right-wing populist Nigel Farage’s Reform UK.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: US to Revoke Chinese Student Visas in Escalating Crackdown
item.description: The US plans to start “aggressively” revoking visas for Chinese students, Secretary of State Marco Rubio said, escalating the Trump administration’s push for greater scrutiny of foreigners attending American universities.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams, Ryan Chua, Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: Photo by Brooks Kraft LLC/Corbis via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Trade Strategy Roiled by Court Blocking Global Tariffs
item.description: President Donald Trump’s tariff strategy has been thrown into turmoil after a US court issued a rare rebuke blocking many of the import taxes he has threatened and imposed on other countries.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan, Erik Larson, Laura Curtis

item.title: China Cut Drone Sales to West But Supplies Them to Russia, Ukraine Says
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said China has stopped selling drones to Kyiv and other European nations while continuing shipments to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: A DJI Mavic 4 Pro drone. Source: NurPhoto/NurPhoto

item.title: Vietnam Blocks Copies of The Economist Over To Lam Cover
item.description: A printed edition of The Economist magazine with Vietnam’s Communist Party General Secretary To Lam on the front cover has been blocked from distribution in the country, in the latest sign of the government’s tightening control over the media.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens

media:content.media:description: To Lam in Hanoi on May 26. Photographer: Chalinee Thirasupa/POOL/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Thai Attorneys Drop Royal Insult Charge Against US Academic
item.description: Thai attorneys have dropped royal insult charges against a US academic citing a lack of evidence, almost two months after he was detained and stripped of his job at a local university.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kutty Abraham

media:content.media:description: A group of foreign tourists walk along the walls of the Royal Palace in Bangkok, Thailand, on Saturday, Feb. 19, 2022. Thailand’s economy looks set to expand by 1.8% year on year in the fourth quarter. Photographer: Luke Duggleby/Bloomberg

item.title: Musk Exits DOGE Leaving Threadbare Agencies and Strained Workers
item.description: The full effects of a drastic cost-cutting campaign are coming into focus as its billionaire architect departs from the government
item.dc:creator: Ted Mann

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk

item.title: Complex Mexican Vote May Be a Double-Edged Sword
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: A volunteer holds a sample ballot in front of the Supreme Court of Justice of the Nation in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. Mexican voters for the first time will elect their judges in a process involving thousands of little-known candidates that could drastically change the balance of power in the country. Photographer: Stephania Corpi/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Boosts Military Push Against China With US Stand Vague
item.description: Japan is stepping up efforts to deter China’s military ambitions in the Asia-Pacific as Tokyo and other US partners seek clarity from the Trump administration about its plans to counter Beijing’s power in the region.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Mari Kiyohara

media:content.media:description: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, center, during his visit to the Philippine Coast Guard Headquarters in Metro Manila, the Philippines, on April 30.
